title: Acoustic Diversity Index Analysis Function - Quick Reference Guide
text:
Before using the function, install required packages:
install.packages(c("tidyverse", "tuneR", "soundecology", "lubridate", 
                   "furrr", "future", "ggridges", "patchwork", "viridis"))



The Acoustic Diversity Index (ADI) is based on the Shannon diversity index and measures how evenly sound energy is distributed across frequency bands.
ADI ranges from 0 to 1: - ADI = 1.0: Sound energy perfectly evenly distributed (maximum diversity) - ADI = 0.0: All sound in one frequency band (minimum diversity) - Higher ADI = More diverse acoustic environment




Divide frequency spectrum into bands (based on freq_step)
Calculate proportion of energy in each band
Apply Shannon index: H = -Œ£(pi √ó ln(pi))
Normalize to 0-1 scale

Only bands above db_threshold are considered ‚Äúoccupied‚Äù and included.



Based on best practices from Villanueva-Rivera et al.¬†(2011):








Parameter
Default
Reason




max_freq
10000 Hz
Captures most bird vocalizations, excludes ultrasonic noise


db_threshold
-50 dB
Standard threshold for ‚Äúoccupied‚Äù frequency bands


freq_step
1000 Hz
1 kHz bands provide good resolution for bird diversity






# Source the function
source("run_adi_analysis.R")

# Run with default settings
results <- run_adi_analysis(
  audio_path = "/path/to/your/recordings",
  output_path = "/path/to/save/outputs"
)

The function creates these files in your output_path:

adi_summary_by_date.csv - Mean/SD/median ADI for each date
adi_summary_by_site.csv - Mean/SD/median ADI for each site
adi_summary_by_deployment.csv - Mean/SD/median ADI for each deployment
adi_analysis_log.txt - Log of processing errors/warnings

  audio_path = "/path/to/recordings",

)

cat("Failed:", results$n_files_failed, "\n")













Soundscape Type
Expected ADI Range
Interpretation




Single species dominant
0.1 - 0.3
Low diversity, sound concentrated


Quiet forest
0.3 - 0.5
Moderate diversity


Active chorus (few species)
0.4 - 0.6
Moderate-high diversity


Diverse dawn chorus
0.6 - 0.8
High diversity, many species


Very complex soundscape
0.8 - 1.0
Very high diversity, even distribution







Dawn Chorus (5-9 AM): Highest ADI - many species vocalizing
Midday (9 AM-5 PM): Lower ADI - reduced vocal activity
Dusk (5-9 PM): Moderate ADI - some evening activity
Night: Variable ADI depending on nocturnal species




Increases ADI: - Multiple species vocalizing across different frequencies - Balanced contributions from different sound sources - Complex acoustic environments
Decreases ADI: - Dominance by single loud species - Sounds concentrated in narrow frequency range - Quiet periods with minimal activity
Can Inflate ADI: - Broadband background noise (wind, rain, traffic) - Recording artifacts across frequencies - Gain settings that amplify quiet bands




If you‚Äôve run ACI, BI, and ADI on the same dataset:
# Load all result sets
aci_data <- read_csv("path/to/aci_raw_results.csv")
bi_data <- read_csv("path/to/bi_raw_results.csv")
adi_data <- read_csv("path/to/adi_raw_results.csv")

# Merge all indices
all_indices <- aci_data %>%
  select(file, site, datetime_local, aci) %>%
  left_join(bi_data %>% select(file, bi), by = "file") %>%
  left_join(adi_data %>% select(file, adi), by = "file")

# Correlation matrix
library(corrr)
all_indices %>%
  select(aci, bi, adi) %>%
  correlate() %>%
  shave() %>%
  fashion()

# Pairwise scatterplots
library(GGally)
all_indices %>%
  select(aci, bi, adi) %>%
  ggpairs() +
  theme_minimal()

# Compare temporal patterns
all_indices %>%
  mutate(hour = hour(datetime_local)) %>%
  group_by(hour) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_aci = mean(aci, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_bi = mean(bi, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_adi = mean(adi, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("mean_"), names_to = "index", values_to = "value") %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = hour, y = value, color = index)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  facet_wrap(~index, scales = "free_y", ncol = 1) +
  labs(title = "Comparison of Acoustic Indices by Hour") +
  theme_minimal()



# Source function
source("run_adi_analysis.R")

# Run comprehensive analysis
results <- run_adi_analysis(
  audio_path = "/data/recordings/Site-A",
  output_path = "/data/analysis/adi_site_a_2024",
  timezone = "America/Los_Angeles",
  max_freq = 10000,
  db_threshold = -50,
  freq_step = 1000,
  n_cores = 8,
  plot_types = c("daily_pattern", "heatmap_daily", "boxplot_period", 
                 "species_correlation", "distribution"),
  figure_width = 14,
  figure_height = 10,
  dpi = 300,
  integrate_birdnet = TRUE
)

# View hourly patterns
print(results$summary_stats$by_hour)

# Examine dawn chorus diversity
dawn_data <- results$adi_results %>%
  filter(time_period == "Dawn") %>%
  group_by(date) %>%
  summarise(mean_dawn_adi = mean(adi, na.rm = TRUE))

# Plot
ggplot(dawn_data, aes(x = date, y = mean_dawn_adi)) +
  geom_line(color = "coral", size = 1) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", color = "darkred") +
  labs(
    title = "Dawn Chorus Acoustic Diversity Over Time",
    x = "Date",
    y = "Mean ADI (Dawn Period)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()



ADI should correlate with species richness if it‚Äôs capturing biological diversity:
# Compare ADI with BirdNET species counts
if (results$birdnet_integrated) {
  
  # Scatterplot
  results$adi_results %>%
    filter(!is.na(adi), !is.na(n_species)) %>%
    ggplot(aes(x = adi, y = n_species)) +
    geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
    geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
    labs(
      title = "ADI vs Species Richness",
      x = "Acoustic Diversity Index",
      y = "Number of Species (BirdNET)"
    ) +
    theme_minimal()
  
  # Calculate correlation
  cor_test <- cor.test(
    results$adi_results$adi, 
    results$adi_results$n_species,
    use = "complete.obs"
  )
  
  print(cor_test)
}






Check db_threshold - may need adjustment
Verify freq_step is appropriate
Check for consistent background noise affecting all recordings





May be picking up broadband noise (wind, rain, traffic)
Consider increasing db_threshold to focus on louder sounds
Check recording quality and gain settings





Single species may be dominating
Check db_threshold - may be too high
Verify frequency range captures target species




# Reduce number of cores
results <- run_adi_analysis(
  audio_path = "/path/to/recordings",
  output_path = "/path/to/outputs",
  n_cores = 2
)




Use ADI when: - Interested in evenness of sound distribution - Want to detect changes in acoustic diversity - Comparing soundscapes with different dominant species - Assessing habitat quality based on sound diversity
ADI complements other indices: - ACI: Measures temporal variability (good for detecting animal sounds) - BI: Measures total bioacoustic activity (good for abundance) - ADI: Measures frequency diversity (good for species richness)
Use all three together for comprehensive acoustic assessment!



Original Paper: - Villanueva-Rivera, L. J., et al.¬†(2011). A primer of acoustic analysis for landscape ecologists. Landscape Ecology, 26(9), 1233-1246.
Methodology: - Pieretti, N., et al.¬†(2011). A new methodology to infer the singing activity of an avian community. Ecological Indicators, 11(3), 868-873.
R Package: - Sueur, J., et al.¬†(2014). Acoustic indices for biodiversity assessment and landscape investigation. Acta Acustica united with Acustica, 100(4), 772-781.
Validation: - Fuller, S., et al.¬†(2015). Connecting soundscape to landscape: Which acoustic index best describes landscape configuration? Ecological Indicators, 58, 207-215.



When presenting ADI results:

Report all parameters: max_freq, db_threshold, freq_step
Show frequency band analysis: Number of active bands over time
Validate with species data: Correlation with field surveys or BirdNET
Compare across habitat types: ADI differences between sites
Consider confounding factors: Noise, weather, recording quality
Use with other indices: ADI alone is not sufficient - combine with ACI, BI
Show temporal patterns: Dawn chorus should show high ADI if functioning correctly

# Band 1: 0-1000 Hz
# Band 2: 1000-2000 Hz
# Band 3: 2000-3000 Hz
# ...
# Band 10: 9000-10000 Hz

# ADI calculates Shannon index across these bands
# If energy is evenly distributed (each band has 10% of total), ADI ‚âà 1.0
# If all energy in one band (one has 100%, others 0%), ADI ‚âà 0.0

This guide provides a complete workflow for analyzing bioacoustic data using four acoustic indices: ACI, BI, ADI, and H.

This analysis suite allows you to: - Calculate four major acoustic biodiversity indices on thousands of audio files in parallel - Integrate results with BirdNET species detections automatically - Generate publication-quality visualizations for each index - Compare all indices with comprehensive statistical analyses - Export publication-ready tables and figures

title: Summary Results
text:
Passive acoustic detection as a means of monitoring species requires that: (1) the animals produce sounds that you can readily attribute to them, and (2) that you have a basic understanding of the variation in both the sounds they produce and the sounds that you detect on your recorder.
While their vocal behavior is well described ((Zembal and Massey 1987), (Massey and Zembal 1987)), understanding variation in relation to the specific methods considered is important to understand the potential (and limitations) of passive acoustic monitoring for population assessment.






Important



Warning: All results are preliminary, data were not acoustically validated!



Temporal Variation
There was considerable daily variation in detection of calls associated with Ridgway‚Äôs Rails at both the Sweetwater Proving Pen #1N (SPP-1N) and at the Tijuana Estuary. Calls from SPP-1N likely included calls sourced from nearby SPP-3S, and this likely explains some of the higher call rate. It is also likely that a higher call rate might be expected due to interaction between the two breeding pairs, as well as interactions with the keepers or false positives due to calling from other birds housed at the Living Coast Discovery Center. Regardless, call rates from captive animals may not reflect call rate in their natural habitat.
This data is preliminary and has not been manually reviewed to confirm detections (add missed calls, remove false positives). Prelminary review found both false positives and false negatives. Future work should include manual review of these data to ensure that calls assigned to Ridgway‚Äôs Rails are in fact calls from those species. This manual review can also be used to validate the classifier, and to develop a more accurate local classifier.
These results suggest that calling behavior may be sufficiently consistent (on a daily basis) to allow for passive acoustic monitoring to assess the populations of Ridgway‚Äôs rails. This pilot study was conducted in late spring through mid-summer, and there may be additional seasonal variation in calling behavior.









The Sunset/Sunrise recordings provided extended duration (increased sample size over time), with recordings ranging from one hour before/after sunrise and one hour before/after sunset. The maximum recording time of less than 6 hours resulted in lower # hours/day with detections, but all dates were non-zero.











Diurnal Variation
There is significant research suggesting that Ridgway‚Äôs Rails call more frequently during the pre-dawn and dusk time periods, and our results agree. Traditional call-response surveys are conducted at dusk (typically) or pre-dawn (rarely) to align with this known increase in calling behavior. Future passive acoustic surveys could limit recording periods to one hour before/after sunrise and sunset. While this would extend the duration between recorder turnover, but would limit the additional context provided by passive acoustic monitoring. At the minimum it would be useful to include some continuous monitoring with some recorders to better understand any variation in diurnal calling behavior (and how this might impact population assessment).
While both locations showed peak calling near dawn and dusk, there were a large number of detections during the day at the Sweetwater Proving Pen (SPP). It is possible that the increased volume of daytime calling was due to this semi-captive environment. There were fewer rail calls at Tijuana Estuary, and little/no calling during the day. Preliminary scanning suggests there may be missed daytime calls. Again, acoustic detections were not manually reviewed and these results should be considered with caution until a review is conducted.









A Binational Light Footed Ridgway‚Äôs Rail Workshop was conducted May 27-29, 2025, with a call-response survey at the Tijuana Estuary ~ 8:30 to 11:30 on Monday May 27. These calls occurred outside the timeframe for either the 48s+s recording configuration (sunrise and sunset), and the continuous recording (48c) ended on May 22. It would be valuable to have overlap in continous recording with future call-response surveys or trainings.





References

This pilot study used Audiomoth recorders to monitor a single location in Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve (TRNERR) as well as a series of acoustic experiments at the Ridgway Rail proving pens at the San Diego Bay National Wildlife Refuge near the Living Coast Discovery Center.

Bird Detection and Classification
Data were first scanned to determine the appropriate Recording Start and Recording End, as the beginning of most recordings contained excessive noise.

title: Future Research
text:
Historical call-response surveys conducted since 1979 have provided a long time-series monitoring of breeding pairs of Ridgway‚Äôs Rails in southern California. This survey design primarily relied on playback of duetting calls to elicit a response from local breeding pairs(Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl 2024); however, specific field methods varied throughout the field season. Notably, (Thompson et al. 2024) noted that these playback methods work well when used sparingly. A recent statistical examination of call-response survey design recommended repeated sampling to decrease sampling bias(Stevens et al. 2024). While historical call-response surveys have proven to be an effective approach to monitoring Ridgway‚Äôs Rails, recent advances in PAM monitoring using acoustic recorders may provide a more standardized approach to monitoring Ridgeway‚Äôs Rails populations that may ultimately lead to more robust estimation of population trends.


Define Primary management needs, and identify secondary research questions that might be met by PAM



This pilot study provides initial data to show a proof of concept and to collect preliminary data useful for developing a potential survey design.



Even though both methods rely on using animal calls to detect the presence of Ridgway‚Äôs rails, it is almost certain that these two methods would provide different population estimates. One is not inherently better than the other; they each have their strengths and limitations.

Regardless, it is imperative that some sampling overlap be conducted in different habitats (or regions) to provide some level of ‚Äòvalidation‚Äô that will aid in interpreting the variation in results.



Acoustic distance sampling methods are well documented, and there are standard software platforms for survey design and data analysis. Still, we highly recommend proactive consultation with a distance sampling statistician prior to implementing a survey design (and ideally for the first set of analysis).



This pilot study used low-cost Audiomoth recorders. As with everything, there are trade-offs with different instruments. It may be that a higher quality recorder may provide a larger detection range or extended recording duration; a larger detection range may require fewer recorders total and an extended recording duration may require fewer field efforts to replace instruments. The total cost estimate should consider these ancillary costs. While consideration of a different recorder will require additional data collection to estimate the detection function, the Sweetwater Proving Pens make this an easy opportunity.
Many bird species are vocal during the morning chorus and (less robustly) near sunset; many passive acoustic studies limit their recordings to these hours in order to extend their recording duration and reduce data sizes. Acoustic data is very rich data, with the potential to provide valuable information on other species of interest, potential impacts due to man-made noise, and other information about the environment. Increasingly, passive acoustics is being used to study insects, biodiversity, and habitat health. I strongly advise for some level of continuous recording in order to provide additional context about the ecosystem.



Antropogenic noise was frequent in these recordings, and there is great potential for negative impacts on animals and the habitat. Noise may lead to masking of vocalizations (so that sounds cannot be detected over the noise), and animals may change their vocal behavior to accommodate increased noise levels. High noise levels may also interfere with their ability to identify the presence of a predator or detect prey. Continous passive acoustic recordings, especially from different regions with different noise impacts, can provide sufficient data to identify changes in vocal behavior due to noise.



Only a very small fraction of the acoustic data collected during this pilot study was examined. This data can be used to assess the potential for studying other bird species (such as threatened or invasive species, or the presence of predators) as well as bats and insects. Several high frequency recordings (192 kHz) are provided as part of this pilot study; these data can provide information related to the presence of bat species feeding in these habitats.
There are several Biodiversity Indices that may provide a means of assessing long term trends. ‚ÄòSoundscape‚Äô levels are increasingly used to assess the level of noise within different frequency bands, and this can be a useful way to assess changes in the environment.



Open science is a global movement to make scientific research and its outcomes freely accessible to everyone. It accelerates scientific progress and strengthens trust in research. This repository is publicly available, and the code and preliminary detection data are provided within this repository. I largely relied on open source software so that results are reproducible. I would recommend that future studies involving PAM extend the use of Open Science to include developing publicly available acoustic classifiers specific to this region, and considering the use of participatory science in data collection and analysis.

title: Population Assessment
text:
To date, population assessment of Ridgway‚Äôs Rails has relied on call-response survey methods conducted by an expert ornithologist. While this long time series has been highly effective, recent research suggests that repeated sampling is required to improve the robustness of the results. Unfortunately, there is evidence that this species may habituate to repeated exposure to call-response surveys, which would lead to worsened outcomes.
Distance sampling methods using visual or passive acoustic detections has proven successful for a wide range of species. Specifically, passive acoustic monitoring using acoustic recording devices placed throughout the habitat may be used as point transect or spatial capture-recapture models to assess population of cryptic species such as Ridgway‚Äôs Rails.

text:
Distance Sampling for Density Estimation
Distance sampling methods using passive acoustic monitoring to estimate density and abundance is being adopted widely. It has great benefits and real limitations that should be considered.
The primary limitation is that animals must be calling to be detected; calling behavior may vary according to any number of behavioral or environmental conditions, which will ultimately affect the downstream data products (population assessment). The more we know about calling behavior, the better we can align models with actual animal density and abundance.
Ultimately, survey design and statistical approach must consider the research question and data products required. Absolute abundance will require a more robust survey design than density or occupancy models. Regardless, a thoughtful survey design will allow for robust assessment of trends over time as well as geographic variation.
Below we provide a few examples to facilitate a discussion of needs, priorities, and potential.

Point Transect Density Estimation


Point transect survey design is a standard approach to density estimation; these methods are well-developed and adopted broadly. Survey design can be developed using random or standardized placement of recorders in the study area (this is facilitated with the dssd R package as shown below).














Acoustic Spatial Capture Recapture (ASCR)


ASCR is an alternative approach to density estimation that can consider additional information related to animal location such as signal strength or time of arrival. ASCR survey design typically considers clustered acoustic recorders where each cluster is distributed such that some calls will be detected on multiple recorders but some calls will not be detected across all recorders (these conditions must be met to apply SCR models). Alternatively, recorders can be placed across the entire study area such that there is overlap in detection across any two or more recorders.

Comparative Studies of Call-Response and Acoustic Distance Sampling Studies
Studies of species such as Ridgway‚Äôs Rails benefit from the animals‚Äô tendency to respond vocally to nearby calls. Research suggests that repeated sampling will decrease sampling bias (Stevens et al. 2024), but other research suggests that animals may habituate and render these methods futile (Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl 2024). Call-response studies provide a measure of the number of animals in a region (abundance), but most call-response studies do not consider how variation in their sampling affects their population estimation. For example, is their ability to detect animals dependent on temporal, environmental or geographic variables? Does the call-response increase their risk by alerting predators to their location? Would an increase in sampling (to decrease bias or to improve seasonal sampling) lead to a decrease in the efficacy of sampling?
While Passive acoustic monitoring (PAM) also relies on the vocal activity of species to study their populations, it is inherently a non-invasive way to remotely sense species‚Äô presence. It necessarily relies on the natural vocal behavior of these species, and therefore is more appropriate for species that can be easily detected and identified to species based on sounds that they voluntarily make. Instead of the single (or limited) call-response sampling, PAM recorders can be deployed year-round to monitor seasonal changes in vocal activity.

text:
The habitat of the endangered light-footed Ridgway‚Äôs rail (Rallus obsoletus levipes) includes wetlands and lagoons in southern California and northern Baja California, Mexico. This species is threatened by habitat degradation and loss, pollution, sea level rise, and non-native species.
Historical call-response surveys conducted since 1979 have provided a long time-series monitoring of breeding pairs of Ridgway‚Äôs Rails in southern California. This survey design primarily relies on playback of duetting calls to elicit a response from local breeding pairs Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl (2024). A recent statistical examination of call-response survey design recommended repeated sampling to decrease sampling bias (Stevens et al. 2024); however, Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl (2024) noted that these playback methods work well when used sparingly. While historical call-response surveys have proven to be an effective approach to monitoring Ridgway‚Äôs Rails, recent advances in Passive Acoustic Monitoring (PAM) using autonomous acoustic recorders may provide a more standardized approach to monitoring Ridgway‚Äôs Rails populations that may ultimately lead to more robust estimation of population trends.
This pilot study serves to identify the potential for PAM surveys as an alternative approach to monitoring the populations of Ridgway‚Äôs Rails in San Diego County. PAM has the added potential benefit of extending temporal monitoring with minimal interference during the sensitive breeding season, providing additional contextual information (anthropogenic impacts, biodiversity), and allowing for opportunities to study other local species and the surrounding habitat.
